segments.pli: 1. Paribbājakakathā
segments.en: 1. Talk on Wanderers

segments.pli: Evaṃ me sutaṃ—
segments.en: So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti mahatā bhikkhusaṃghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was traveling along the road between Rājagaha and Nālanda together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants.

segments.pli: Suppiyopi kho paribbājako antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti saddhiṃ antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena.
segments.en: The wanderer Suppiya was also traveling along the same road, together with his pupil, the brahmin student Brahmadatta.

segments.pli: Tatra sudaṃ suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṃghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati;
segments.en: Meanwhile, Suppiya criticized the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,

segments.pli: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṃghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
segments.en: but his pupil Brahmadatta praised them in many ways.

segments.pli: Itiha te ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti bhikkhusaṃghañca.
segments.en: And so both teacher and pupil followed behind the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants directly contradicting each other.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ rājāgārake ekarattivāsaṃ upagacchi saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṃghena.
segments.en: Then the Buddha took up residence for the night in the royal rest-house in Ambalaṭṭhikā together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.

segments.pli: Suppiyopi kho paribbājako ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ rājāgārake ekarattivāsaṃ upagacchi antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena.
segments.en: And Suppiya and Brahmadatta did likewise.

segments.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṃghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati;
segments.en: There too, Suppiya criticized the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,

segments.pli: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṃghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
segments.en: but his pupil Brahmadatta praised them in many ways.

segments.pli: Itiha te ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā viharanti.
segments.en: And so both teacher and pupil kept on directly contradicting each other.

segments.pli: Atha kho sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhitānaṃ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayaṃ saṅkhiyadhammo udapādi:
segments.en: Then several mendicants rose at the crack of dawn and sat together in the pavilion, where the topic of evaluation came up:

segments.pli: “acchariyaṃ, āvuso, abbhutaṃ, āvuso, yāvañcidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sattānaṃ nānādhimuttikatā suppaṭividitā.
segments.en: “It’s incredible, reverends, it’s amazing how the diverse attitudes of sentient beings have been clearly comprehended by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

segments.pli: Ayañhi suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati;
segments.en: For this Suppiya criticizes the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,

segments.pli: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
segments.en: while his pupil Brahmadatta praises them in many ways.

segments.pli: Itihame ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti bhikkhusaṅghañcā”ti.
segments.en: And so both teacher and pupil followed behind the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants directly contradicting each other.”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ imaṃ saṅkhiyadhammaṃ viditvā yena maṇḍalamāḷo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: When the Buddha found out about this discussion on evaluation among the mendicants, he went to the pavilion, where he sat on the seat spread out and addressed the mendicants,

segments.pli: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā sannipatitā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
segments.en: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: The mendicants told him what had happened, adding,

segments.pli: “idha, bhante, amhākaṃ rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhitānaṃ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayaṃ saṅkhiyadhammo udapādi:
‘acchariyaṃ, āvuso, abbhutaṃ, āvuso, yāvañcidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sattānaṃ nānādhimuttikatā suppaṭividitā.
Ayañhi suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati;
suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
Itihame ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti bhikkhusaṅghañcā’ti.
Ayaṃ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
segments.en: “This was our conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”

segments.pli: “Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra tumhehi na āghāto na appaccayo na cetaso anabhiraddhi karaṇīyā.
segments.en: “Mendicants, if others criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, don’t make yourselves resentful, bitter, and exasperated.

segments.pli: Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitā vā anattamanā vā, tumhaṃ yevassa tena antarāyo.
segments.en: You’ll get angry and upset, which would be an obstacle for you alone.

segments.pli: Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitā vā anattamanā vā, api nu tumhe paresaṃ subhāsitaṃ dubbhāsitaṃ ājāneyyāthā”ti?
segments.en: If others were to criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, and you got angry and upset, would you be able to understand whether they spoke well or poorly?”

segments.pli: “No hetaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “No, sir.”

segments.pli: “Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra tumhehi abhūtaṃ abhūtato nibbeṭhetabbaṃ:
segments.en: “If others criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, you should explain that what is untrue is in fact untrue:

segments.pli: ‘itipetaṃ abhūtaṃ, itipetaṃ atacchaṃ, natthi cetaṃ amhesu, na ca panetaṃ amhesu saṃvijjatī’ti.
segments.en: ‘This is why that’s untrue, this is why that’s false. There’s no such thing in us, it’s not found among us.’

segments.pli: Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṃghassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra tumhehi na ānando na somanassaṃ na cetaso uppilāvitattaṃ karaṇīyaṃ.
segments.en: If others praise me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, don’t make yourselves thrilled, elated, and excited.

segments.pli: Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṃghassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra ce tumhe assatha ānandino sumanā uppilāvitā tumhaṃ yevassa tena antarāyo.
segments.en: You’ll get thrilled, elated, and excited, which would be an obstacle for you alone.

segments.pli: Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṃghassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra tumhehi bhūtaṃ bhūtato paṭijānitabbaṃ:
segments.en: If others praise me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, you should acknowledge that what is true is in fact true:

segments.pli: ‘itipetaṃ bhūtaṃ, itipetaṃ tacchaṃ, atthi cetaṃ amhesu, saṃvijjati ca panetaṃ amhesū’ti.
segments.en: ‘This is why that’s true, this is why that’s correct. There is such a thing in us, it is found among us.’

segments.pli: 2. Sīla
segments.en: 2. Ethics

segments.pli: 2.1. Cūḷasīla
segments.en: 2.1. The Shorter Section on Ethics

segments.pli: Appamattakaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, oramattakaṃ sīlamattakaṃ, yena puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: When an ordinary person speaks praise of the Realized One, they speak only of trivial, insignificant details of mere ethics.

segments.pli: Katamañca taṃ, bhikkhave, appamattakaṃ oramattakaṃ sīlamattakaṃ, yena puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya?
segments.en: And what are the trivial, insignificant details of mere ethics that an ordinary person speaks of?

segments.pli: ‘Pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo nihitadaṇḍo, nihitasattho, lajjī, dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharatī’ti—
segments.en: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up killing living creatures. He has renounced the rod and the sword. He’s scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharatī’ti—
segments.en: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up stealing. He takes only what’s given, and expects only what’s given. He keeps himself clean by not thieving.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī samaṇo gotamo ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā’ti—
segments.en: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up unchastity. He is celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassā’ti—
segments.en: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up lying. He speaks the truth and sticks to the truth. He’s honest and trustworthy, and doesn’t trick the world with his words.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo, ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā amūsaṃ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā, sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā’ti—
segments.en: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up divisive speech. He doesn’t repeat in one place what he heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, he reconciles those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo, yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā’ti—
segments.en: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up harsh speech. He speaks in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhitan’ti—
segments.en: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up talking nonsense. His words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. He says things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: ‘The ascetic Gotama refrains from injuring plants and seeds.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave … pe ….
‘Ekabhattiko samaṇo gotamo rattūparato virato vikālabhojanā ….
segments.en: ‘He eats in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.’

segments.pli: Naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: ‘He refrains from dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows.’

segments.pli: Mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: ‘He refrains from beautifying and adorning himself with garlands, perfumes, and makeup.’

segments.pli: Uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: ‘He refrains from high and luxurious beds.’

segments.pli: Jātarūparajatapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: ‘He refrains from receiving gold and money,

segments.pli: Āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: raw grains,

segments.pli: Āmakamaṃsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: raw meat,

segments.pli: Itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: women and girls,

segments.pli: Dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: male and female bondservants,

segments.pli: Ajeḷakapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: goats and sheep,

segments.pli: Kukkuṭasūkarapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: chickens and pigs,

segments.pli: Hatthigavassavaḷavapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: elephants, cows, horses, and mares,

segments.pli: Khettavatthupaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: and fields and land.’

segments.pli: Dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: ‘He refrains from running errands and messages;

segments.pli: Kayavikkayā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: buying and selling;

segments.pli: Tulākūṭakaṃsakūṭamānakūṭā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: falsifying weights, metals, or measures;

segments.pli: Ukkoṭanavañcananikatisāciyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo ….
segments.en: bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity;

segments.pli: Chedanavadhabandhanaviparāmosaālopasahasākārā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: Cūḷasīlaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
segments.en: The shorter section on ethics is finished.

segments.pli: 2.2. Majjhimasīla
segments.en: 2.2. The Middle Section on Ethics

segments.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in injuring plants and seeds.

segments.pli: seyyathidaṃ—mūlabījaṃ khandhabījaṃ phaḷubījaṃ aggabījaṃ bījabījameva pañcamaṃ;
segments.en: These include plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth.

segments.pli: iti evarūpā bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such injury to plants and seeds.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ sannidhikāraparibhogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in storing up goods for their own use.

segments.pli: seyyathidaṃ—annasannidhiṃ pānasannidhiṃ vatthasannidhiṃ yānasannidhiṃ sayanasannidhiṃ gandhasannidhiṃ āmisasannidhiṃ
segments.en: This includes such things as food, drink, clothes, vehicles, bedding, fragrance, and material possessions.

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā sannidhikāraparibhogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from storing up such goods.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ visūkadassanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in seeing shows.

segments.pli: seyyathidaṃ—naccaṃ gītaṃ vāditaṃ pekkhaṃ akkhānaṃ pāṇissaraṃ vetāḷaṃ kumbhathūṇaṃ sobhanakaṃ caṇḍālaṃ vaṃsaṃ dhovanaṃ hatthiyuddhaṃ assayuddhaṃ mahiṃsayuddhaṃ usabhayuddhaṃ ajayuddhaṃ meṇḍayuddhaṃ kukkuṭayuddhaṃ vaṭṭakayuddhaṃ daṇḍayuddhaṃ muṭṭhiyuddhaṃ nibbuddhaṃ uyyodhikaṃ balaggaṃ senābyūhaṃ anīkadassanaṃ
segments.en: This includes such things as dancing, singing, music, performances, and storytelling; clapping, gongs, and kettle-drums; art exhibitions and acrobatic displays; battles of elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, goats, rams, chickens, and quails; staff-fights, boxing, and wrestling; combat, roll calls of the armed forces, battle-formations, and regimental reviews.

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā visūkadassanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such shows.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in gambling that causes negligence.

segments.pli: seyyathidaṃ—aṭṭhapadaṃ dasapadaṃ ākāsaṃ parihārapathaṃ santikaṃ khalikaṃ ghaṭikaṃ salākahatthaṃ akkhaṃ paṅgacīraṃ vaṅkakaṃ mokkhacikaṃ ciṅgulikaṃ pattāḷhakaṃ rathakaṃ dhanukaṃ akkharikaṃ manesikaṃ yathāvajjaṃ
segments.en: This includes such things as checkers, draughts, checkers in the air, hopscotch, spillikins, board-games, tip-cat, drawing straws, dice, leaf-flutes, toy plows, somersaults, pinwheels, toy measures, toy carts, toy bows, guessing words from syllables, and guessing another’s thoughts.

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such gambling.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still make use of high and luxurious bedding.

segments.pli: seyyathidaṃ—āsandiṃ pallaṅkaṃ gonakaṃ cittakaṃ paṭikaṃ paṭalikaṃ tūlikaṃ vikatikaṃ uddalomiṃ ekantalomiṃ kaṭṭissaṃ koseyyaṃ kuttakaṃ hatthattharaṃ assattharaṃ rathattharaṃ ajinappaveṇiṃ kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇaṃ sauttaracchadaṃ ubhatolohitakūpadhānaṃ
segments.en: This includes such things as sofas, couches, woolen covers—shag-piled, colorful, white, embroidered with flowers, quilted, embroidered with animals, double- or single-fringed—and silk covers studded with gems, as well as silken sheets, woven carpets, rugs for elephants, horses, or chariots, antelope hide rugs, and spreads of fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red cushions at both ends.

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such bedding.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ maṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.

segments.pli: ucchādanaṃ parimaddanaṃ nhāpanaṃ sambāhanaṃ ādāsaṃ añjanaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ mukhacuṇṇaṃ mukhalepanaṃ hatthabandhaṃ sikhābandhaṃ daṇḍaṃ nāḷikaṃ asiṃ chattaṃ citrupāhanaṃ uṇhīsaṃ maṇiṃ vālabījaniṃ odātāni vatthāni dīghadasāni
segments.en: This includes such things as applying beauty products by anointing, massaging, bathing, and rubbing; mirrors, ointments, garlands, fragrances, and makeup; face-powder, foundation, bracelets, headbands, fancy walking-sticks or containers, rapiers, parasols, fancy sandals, turbans, jewelry, chowries, and long-fringed white robes.

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā maṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such beautification and adornment.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in unworthy talk. This includes such topics as

segments.pli: seyyathidaṃ—rājakathaṃ corakathaṃ mahāmattakathaṃ senākathaṃ bhayakathaṃ yuddhakathaṃ annakathaṃ pānakathaṃ vatthakathaṃ sayanakathaṃ mālākathaṃ gandhakathaṃ ñātikathaṃ yānakathaṃ gāmakathaṃ nigamakathaṃ nagarakathaṃ janapadakathaṃ itthikathaṃ sūrakathaṃ visikhākathaṃ kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṃ pubbapetakathaṃ nānattakathaṃ lokakkhāyikaṃ samuddakkhāyikaṃ itibhavābhavakathaṃ
segments.en: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānakathāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such unworthy talk.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.

segments.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ viggāhikakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in arguments.

segments.pli: seyyathidaṃ—na tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāsi, ahaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāmi, kiṃ tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānissasi, micchā paṭipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammā paṭipanno, sahitaṃ me, asahitaṃ te, purevacanīyaṃ pacchā avaca, pacchāvacanīyaṃ pure avaca, adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattaṃ, āropito te vādo, niggahito tvamasi, cara vādappamokkhāya, nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosīti
segments.en: They say such things as: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya viggāhikakathāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such argumentative talk.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in running errands and messages.

segments.pli: seyyathidaṃ—raññaṃ, rājamahāmattānaṃ, khattiyānaṃ, brāhmaṇānaṃ, gahapatikānaṃ, kumārānaṃ “idha gaccha, amutrāgaccha, idaṃ hara, amutra idaṃ āharā”ti
segments.en: This includes running errands for rulers, ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or princes who say: “Go here, go there. Take this, bring that from there.”

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such errands.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te kuhakā ca honti, lapakā ca nemittikā ca nippesikā ca, lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsitāro ca
segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in deceit, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material possessions to pursue other material possessions.

segments.pli: iti evarūpā kuhanalapanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such deceit and flattery.’

segments.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
segments.en: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

segments.en: The middle section on ethics is finished.

segments.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti,
segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by unworthy branches of knowledge, by wrong livelihood.

segments.pli: seyyathidaṃ—aṅgaṃ nimittaṃ uppātaṃ supinaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ mūsikacchinnaṃ aggihomaṃ dabbihomaṃ thusahomaṃ kaṇahomaṃ taṇḍulahomaṃ sappihomaṃ telahomaṃ mukhahomaṃ lohitahomaṃ aṅgavijjā vatthuvijjā khattavijjā sivavijjā bhūtavijjā bhūrivijjā ahivijjā visavijjā vicchikavijjā mūsikavijjā sakuṇavijjā vāyasavijjā pakkajjhānaṃ saraparittāṇaṃ migacakkaṃ
segments.en: This includes such fields as limb-reading, omenology, divining celestial portents, interpreting dreams, divining bodily marks, divining holes in cloth gnawed by mice, fire offerings, ladle offerings, offerings of husks, rice powder, rice, ghee, or oil; offerings from the mouth, blood sacrifices, palmistry; geomancy for building sites, fields, and cemeteries; exorcisms, earth magic, snake charming, poisons; the crafts of the scorpion, the rat, the bird, and the crow; prophesying life span, chanting for protection, and animal cries.

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
segments.en: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such unworthy branches of knowledge, such wrong livelihood.’

segments.en: This includes reading the marks of gems, cloth, clubs, swords, spears, arrows, weapons, women, men, boys, girls, male and female bondservants, elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, cows, goats, rams, chickens, quails, monitor lizards, rabbits, tortoises, or deer.

segments.en: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by unworthy branches of knowledge, by wrong livelihood.

segments.en: This includes making predictions that the king will march forth or march back; or that our king will attack and the enemy king will retreat, or vice versa; or that our king will triumph and the enemy king will be defeated, or vice versa; and so there will be victory for one and defeat for the other.

segments.en: This includes making predictions that there will be an eclipse of the moon, or sun, or stars; that the sun, moon, and stars will be in conjunction or in opposition; that there will be a meteor shower, a fiery sky, an earthquake, thunder; that there will be a rising, a setting, a darkening, a brightening of the moon, sun, and stars. segments.en: This includes predicting whether there will be plenty of rain or drought; plenty to eat or famine; an abundant harvest or a bad harvest; security or peril; sickness or health. It also includes such occupations as computing, accounting, calculating, poetry, and cosmology.

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—

segments.en: This includes making arrangements for giving and taking in marriage; for engagement and divorce; and for scattering rice inwards or outwards at the wedding ceremony. It also includes casting spells for good or bad luck, curses to prevent conception, bind the tongue, or lock the jaws; charms for the hands and ears; questioning a mirror, a girl, or a god as an oracle; worshiping the sun, worshiping the Great One, breathing fire, and invoking Siri, the goddess of luck.

segments.en: This includes rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving rinsing and bathing, and oblations. It also includes administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, prescribing root medicines, and binding on herbs.

segments.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—

segments.en: These are the trivial, insignificant details of mere ethics that an ordinary person speaks of when they speak praise of the Realized One.

segments.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, aññeva dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
segments.en: There are other principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of reason, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. Those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

segments.pli: Katame ca te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ?
segments.en: And what are these principles?

segments.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino, pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi.
segments.en: There are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the past, and assert various hypotheses concerning the past on eighteen grounds.

segments.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi?
segments.en: And what are the eighteen grounds on which they rely?

segments.en: 3.1.1. Eternalism

segments.en: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are eternalists, who assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal on four grounds.

segments.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekānipi jātisatāni anekānipi jātisahassāni anekānipi jātisatasahassāni: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

segments.en: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal do so on one or other of these four grounds. Outside of this there is none.

segments.pli: Paṭhamabhāṇavāro.
3.1.2. Ekaccasassatavāda
segments.en: 3.1.2. Partial Eternalism

segments.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
segments.en: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are partial eternalists, who assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal and partially not eternal on four grounds.

segments.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi?
segments.en: And what are the four grounds on which they rely?

segments.pli: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaṃ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṃ loko saṃvaṭṭati.
segments.en: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos contracts.

segments.pli: Saṃvaṭṭamāne loke yebhuyyena sattā ābhassarasaṃvattanikā honti.
segments.en: As the cosmos contracts, sentient beings are mostly headed for the realm of streaming radiance.

segments.pli: Te tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti.
segments.en: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the sky, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

segments.pli: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaṃ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṃ loko vivaṭṭati.
segments.en: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos expands.

segments.pli: Vivaṭṭamāne loke suññaṃ brahmavimānaṃ pātubhavati.
segments.en: As it expands an empty mansion of Brahmā appears.

segments.pli: Atha kho aññataro satto āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā suññaṃ brahmavimānaṃ upapajjati.
segments.en: Then a certain sentient being—due to the running out of their life-span or merit—passes away from that host of radiant deities and is reborn in that empty mansion of Brahmā.

segments.pli: So tattha hoti manomayo pītibhakkho sayampabho antalikkhacaro subhaṭṭhāyī, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhati.
segments.en: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the sky, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

segments.pli: Tassa tattha ekakassa dīgharattaṃ nivusitattā anabhirati paritassanā uppajjati:
segments.en: But after staying there all alone for a long time, they become dissatisfied and anxious:

segments.pli: ‘aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṃ āgaccheyyun’ti.
segments.en: ‘Oh, if only another being would come to this state of existence.’

segments.pli: Atha aññepi sattā āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā brahmavimānaṃ upapajjanti tassa sattassa sahabyataṃ.
segments.en: Then other sentient beings—due to the running out of their life-span or merit—pass away from that host of radiant deities and are reborn in that empty mansion of Brahmā in company with that being.

segments.pli: Tepi tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti.
segments.en: There they too are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the sky, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

segments.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo so satto paṭhamaṃ upapanno tassa evaṃ hoti:
segments.en: Now, the being who was reborn there first thinks:

segments.pli: ‘ahamasmi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ.
segments.en: ‘I am Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Undefeated, the Champion, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, the Lord God, the Maker, the Author, the Best, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.

segments.pli: Mayā ime sattā nimmitā.
segments.en: These beings were created by me!

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Mamañhi pubbe etadahosi:
segments.en: Because first I thought:

segments.pli: “aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṃ āgaccheyyun”ti.
segments.en: “Oh, if only another being would come to this state of existence.”

segments.pli: Iti mama ca manopaṇidhi, ime ca sattā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti.
segments.en: Such was my heart’s wish, and then these creatures came to this state of existence.’

segments.pli: Yepi te sattā pacchā upapannā, tesampi evaṃ hoti:
segments.en: And the beings who were reborn there later also think:

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho bhavaṃ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ.
segments.en: ‘This must be Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Undefeated, the Champion, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, the Lord God, the Maker, the Author, the Best, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.

segments.pli: Iminā mayaṃ bhotā brahmunā nimmitā.
segments.en: And we have been created by him.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Imañhi mayaṃ addasāma idha paṭhamaṃ upapannaṃ, mayaṃ panamha pacchā upapannā’ti.
segments.en: Because we see that he was reborn here first, and we arrived later.’

segments.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo so satto paṭhamaṃ upapanno, so dīghāyukataro ca hoti vaṇṇavantataro ca mahesakkhataro ca.
segments.en: And the being who was reborn first is more long-lived, beautiful, and illustrious than those who arrived later.

segments.pli: Ye pana te sattā pacchā upapannā, te appāyukatarā ca honti dubbaṇṇatarā ca appesakkhatarā ca.
Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
segments.en: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this state of existence.

segments.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
segments.en: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

segments.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati.
segments.en: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.

segments.pli: So evamāha:
segments.en: They say:

segments.pli: ‘yo kho so bhavaṃ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ, yena mayaṃ bhotā brahmunā nimmitā, so nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassati.
segments.en: ‘He who is Brahmā—the Great Brahmā, the Undefeated, the Champion, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, the Lord God, the Maker, the Author, the Best, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born—is permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.

segments.pli: Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā tena bhotā brahmunā nimmitā, te mayaṃ aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti.
segments.en: We who were created by that Brahmā are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, perishable, and have come to this state of existence.

segments.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti. (1: 5)
segments.en: This is the first ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal.

segments.pli: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
segments.en: And what is the second ground on which they rely?

segments.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, khiḍḍāpadosikā nāma devā, te ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharanti. Tesaṃ ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati sammussati. Satiyā sammosā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
segments.en: There are gods named ‘depraved by play.’ They spend too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. And in doing so, they lose their mindfulness, and they pass away from that host of gods.

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
segments.en: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this state of existence.

segments.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
segments.en: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

segments.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati.
segments.en: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.

segments.pli: So evamāha:
segments.en: They say:

segments.pli: ‘ye kho te bhonto devā na khiḍḍāpadosikā, te na ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharanti. Tesaṃ na ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati na sammussati. Satiyā asammosā te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti;
segments.en: ‘The gods not depraved by play don’t spend too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. So they don’t lose their mindfulness, and don’t pass away from that host of gods.

segments.pli: niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassanti.
segments.en: They are permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.

segments.pli: Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā khiḍḍāpadosikā, te mayaṃ ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharimhā. Tesaṃ no ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati sammussati. Satiyā sammosā evaṃ mayaṃ tamhā kāyā cutā
segments.en: But we who were depraved by play spent too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. In doing so, we lost our mindfulness, and passed away from that host of gods.

segments.pli: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti.
segments.en: We are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, perishable, and have come to this state of existence.’

segments.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti. (2: 6)
segments.en: This is the second ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal.

segments.pli: Tatiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
segments.en: And what is the third ground on which they rely?

segments.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, manopadosikā nāma devā, te ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyanti. Te ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsenti. Te aññamaññaṃ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
segments.en: There are gods named ‘malevolent’. They spend too much time gazing at each other, so they grow angry with each other, and their bodies and minds get tired. They pass away from that host of gods.

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
segments.en: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this state of existence.

segments.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
segments.en: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

segments.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati.
segments.en: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.

segments.pli: So evamāha:
segments.en: They say:

segments.pli: ‘ye kho te bhonto devā na manopadosikā, te nātivelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyanti. Te nātivelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni nappadūsenti. Te aññamaññaṃ appaduṭṭhacittā akilantakāyā akilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti,
segments.en: ‘The gods who are not malevolent don’t spend too much time gazing at each other, so they don’t grow angry with each other, their bodies and minds don’t get tired, and they don’t pass away from that host of gods.

segments.pli: niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassanti.
segments.en: They are permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.

segments.pli: Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā manopadosikā, te mayaṃ ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyimhā. Te mayaṃ ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsimhā, te mayaṃ aññamaññaṃ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Evaṃ mayaṃ tamhā kāyā cutā
segments.en: But we who were malevolent spent too much time gazing at each other, we grew angry with each other, our bodies and minds got tired, and we passed away from that host of gods.

segments.pli: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti.
segments.en: We are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, perishable, and have come to this state of existence.’

segments.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti. (3: 7)
segments.en: This is the third ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal.

segments.pli: Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
segments.en: And what is the fourth ground on which they rely?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṃsī. So takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānaṃ evamāha:
segments.en: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry. They speak of what they have worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing their own perspective:

segments.pli: ‘yaṃ kho idaṃ vuccati cakkhuṃ itipi sotaṃ itipi ghānaṃ itipi jivhā itipi kāyo itipi, ayaṃ attā anicco addhuvo asassato vipariṇāmadhammo.
segments.en: ‘That which is called “the eye” or “the ear” or “the nose” or “the tongue” or “the body”: that self is impermanent, not lasting, transient, perishable.

segments.pli: Yañca kho idaṃ vuccati cittanti vā manoti vā viññāṇanti vā ayaṃ attā nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassatī’ti.
segments.en: That which is called “mind” or “sentience” or “consciousness”: that self is permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.’

segments.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti. (4: 8)
segments.en: This is the fourth ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal.

segments.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
segments.en: These are the four grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal and partially not eternal.

segments.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.
segments.en: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal and partially not eternal do so on one or other of these four grounds. Outside of this there is none.

segments.pli: Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti:
segments.en: The Realized One understands this:

segments.pli: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti.
segments.en: ‘If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views it leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.’

segments.pli: Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
segments.en: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. Yet since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized extinguishment within himself.

segments.pli: Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
segments.en: Having truly understood the origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape from feelings, the Realized One is freed through not grasping.

segments.pli: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
segments.en: These are the principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of reason, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

segments.pli: 3.1.3. Antānantavāda
segments.en: 3.1.3. The Cosmos is Finite or Infinite

segments.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
segments.en: There are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about size, and assert that the cosmos is finite or infinite on four grounds.

segments.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi?
segments.en: And what are the four grounds on which they rely?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati.
segments.en: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they meditate perceiving the cosmos as finite.

segments.pli: So evamāha:
segments.en: They say:

segments.pli: ‘antavā ayaṃ loko parivaṭumo.
segments.en: ‘The cosmos is finite and bounded.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharāmi.
segments.en: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I meditate perceiving the cosmos as finite.

segments.pli: Imināmahaṃ etaṃ jānāmi:
segments.en: Because of this I know:

segments.pli: “yathā antavā ayaṃ loko parivaṭumo”’ti.
segments.en: “The cosmos is finite and bounded.”’

segments.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti. (1: 9)
segments.en: This is the first ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the cosmos is finite or infinite.

segments.pli: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti?
segments.en: And what is the second ground on which they rely?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte anantasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati.
segments.en: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they meditate perceiving the cosmos as infinite.

segments.pli: So evamāha:
segments.en: They say:

segments.pli: ‘ananto ayaṃ loko apariyanto.
segments.en: ‘The cosmos is infinite and unbounded.

segments.pli: Ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu:
segments.en: The ascetics and brahmins who say that

segments.pli: “antavā ayaṃ loko parivaṭumo”ti, tesaṃ musā.
segments.en: the cosmos is finite are wrong.

segments.pli: Ananto ayaṃ loko apariyanto.
segments.en: The cosmos is infinite and unbounded.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte anantasaññī lokasmiṃ viharāmi.
segments.en: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I meditate perceiving the cosmos as infinite.

segments.pli: Imināmahaṃ etaṃ jānāmi:
segments.en: Because of this I know:

segments.pli: “yathā ananto ayaṃ loko apariyanto”’ti.
segments.en: “The cosmos is infinite and unbounded.”’

segments.en: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they meditate perceiving the cosmos as finite vertically but infinite horizontally.

segments.en: ‘The cosmos is both finite and infinite.

segments.en: The ascetics and brahmins who say that

segments.pli: “antavā ayaṃ loko parivaṭumo”ti, tesaṃ musā.
segments.en: the cosmos is finite are wrong,

segments.pli: Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu:
segments.en: and so are those who say that

segments.pli: “ananto ayaṃ loko apariyanto”ti, tesampi musā.
segments.en: the cosmos is infinite.

segments.en: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I meditate perceiving the cosmos as finite vertically but infinite horizontally.

segments.en: Because of this I know:

segments.en: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry. They speak of what they have worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing their own perspective:

segments.pli: ‘nevāyaṃ loko antavā, na panānanto.
segments.en: ‘The cosmos is neither finite nor infinite.

segments.pli: Ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu:
segments.en: The ascetics and brahmins who say that

segments.en: and also those who say that

segments.en: the cosmos is both finite and infinite.

segments.en: ‘If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views it leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.’

segments.pli: Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
segments.en: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. Yet since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized extinguishment within himself.

segments.pli: Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
segments.en: Having truly understood the origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape from feelings, the Realized One is freed through not grasping.

segments.pli: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.

segments.pli: 3.1.4. Amarāvikkhepavāda
segments.en: 3.1.4. Equivocators

segments.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā, tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi.
segments.en: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are equivocators. Whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to evasiveness and equivocation on four grounds.

segments.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi?
segments.en: And what are the four grounds on which they rely?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘idaṃ kusalan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ‘idaṃ akusalan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
segments.en: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin doesn’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.

segments.pli: Tassa evaṃ hoti:
segments.en: They think:

segments.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho “idaṃ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi, “idaṃ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi.
segments.en: ‘I don’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.

segments.pli: Ahañce kho pana “idaṃ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto, “idaṃ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto, “idaṃ kusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṃ, “idaṃ akusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṃ, taṃ mamassa musā.
segments.en: If I were to declare that something was skillful or unskillful I might be wrong.

segments.pli: Yaṃ mamassa musā, so mamassa vighāto.
segments.en: That would be stressful for me,

segments.pli: Yo mamassa vighāto so mamassa antarāyo’ti.
segments.en: and that stress would be an obstacle.’

segments.pli: Iti so musāvādabhayā musāvādaparijegucchā nevidaṃ kusalanti byākaroti, na panidaṃ akusalanti byākaroti, tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṃ:
segments.en: So from fear and disgust with false speech they avoid stating whether something is skillful or unskillful. Whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to evasiveness and equivocation:

segments.pli: ‘evantipi me no; tathātipi me no; aññathātipi me no; notipi me no; no notipi me no’ti.
segments.en: ‘I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’

segments.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, asaññasattā nāma devā.

segments.pli: Saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
segments.en: When perception arises they pass away from that host of gods.

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
segments.en: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this state of existence.

segments.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
segments.en: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

segments.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte saññuppādaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati.
segments.en: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect the arising of perception, but no further.

segments.pli: So evamāha:
segments.en: They say:

segments.pli: ‘adhiccasamuppanno attā ca loko ca.
segments.en: ‘The self and the cosmos arose by chance.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Ahañhi pubbe nāhosiṃ, somhi etarahi ahutvā santatāya pariṇato’ti.
segments.en: Because formerly I didn’t exist. Now, having not been, I’ve sprung into existence.’

segments.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti. (1: 17)
segments.en: This is the first ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos arose by chance.

segments.pli: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
segments.en: And what is the second ground on which they rely?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṃsī.
segments.en: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry.

segments.pli: So takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānaṃ evamāha:
segments.en: They speak of what they have worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing their own perspective:

segments.pli: ‘adhiccasamuppanno attā ca loko cā’ti.
segments.en: ‘The self and the cosmos arose by chance.’

segments.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti. (2: 18)
segments.en: This is the second ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos arose by chance.

segments.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi.
segments.en: These are the two grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who theorize about chance assert that the self and the cosmos arose by chance.

segments.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva dvīhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā …
segments.en: Any ascetics and brahmins who theorize about chance do so on one or other of these two grounds. Outside of this there is none.

segments.en: These are the eighteen grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the past assert various hypotheses concerning the past.

segments.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantamārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā.

segments.pli: Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti:
segments.en: The Realized One understands this:

segments.pli: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti.
segments.en: ‘If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views it leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.’

segments.pli: Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
segments.en: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. Yet since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized extinguishment within himself.

segments.pli: Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
segments.en: Having truly understood the origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape from feelings, the Realized One is freed through not grasping.

segments.pli: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
segments.en: These are the principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of reason, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

3.2. Aparantakappika
segments.en: 3.2. Theories About the Future

segments.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino, aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi.
segments.en: There are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the future, and assert various hypotheses concerning the future on forty-four grounds.

segments.en: And what are the forty-four grounds on which they rely?

segments.pli: 3.2.4. Ucchedavāda
segments.en: 3.2.4. Annihilationism

segments.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi.
segments.en: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are annihilationists. They assert the annihilation, eradication, and obliteration of an existing being on seven grounds.

segments.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi?
segments.en: And what are the seven grounds on which they rely?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi:
segments.en: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

segments.pli: ‘yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti.
segments.en: ‘This self is physical, made up of the four primary elements, and produced by mother and father. Since it’s annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death, that’s how this self becomes rightly annihilated.’

segments.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti. (1: 51)
segments.en: That is how some assert the annihilation of an existing being.

segments.en: But someone else says to them:

segments.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
segments.en: ‘*That* self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

segments.en: But that’s not how *this* self becomes rightly annihilated.

segments.pli: 3.2.5. Diṭṭhadhammanibbānavāda
segments.en: 3.2.5. Extinguishment in the Present Life

segments.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi.
segments.en: There are some ascetics and brahmins who speak of extinguishment in the present life. They assert the ultimate extinguishment of an existing being in the present life on five grounds.

segments.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi?
segments.en: And what are the five grounds on which they rely?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi:
segments.en: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

segments.pli: ‘yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti.
segments.en: ‘When this self amuses itself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, that’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.’

segments.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti. (1: 58)
segments.en: That is how some assert the extinguishment of an existing being in the present life.

segments.pli: Tamañño evamāha:
segments.en: But someone else says to them:

segments.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
segments.en: ‘*That* self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

segments.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti.
segments.en: But that’s not how *this* self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Kāmā hi, bho, aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, tesaṃ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
segments.en: Because sensual pleasures are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Their decay and perishing give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

segments.pli: Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti.
segments.en: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, this self enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.’

segments.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti. (2: 59)
segments.en: That is how some assert the extinguishment of an existing being in the present life.

segments.pli: Tamañño evamāha:
segments.en: But someone else says to them:

segments.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti.
segments.en: But that’s not how *this* self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Yadeva tattha vitakkitaṃ vicāritaṃ, etenetaṃ oḷārikaṃ akkhāyati.
segments.en: Because the placing of the mind and the keeping it connected there are coarse.

segments.pli: Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti.
segments.en: But when the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, this self enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.’

segments.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti. (3: 60)
segments.en: That is how some assert the extinguishment of an existing being in the present life.

segments.pli: Tamañño evamāha:
segments.en: But someone else says to them:

segments.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;

segments.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti.
segments.en: But that’s not how *this* self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Yadeva tattha pītigataṃ cetaso uppilāvitattaṃ, etenetaṃ oḷārikaṃ akkhāyati.
segments.en: Because the rapture and emotional excitement there are coarse.

segments.pli: Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti “upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī”ti, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti.
segments.en: But with the fading away of rapture, this self enters and remains in the third absorption, where it meditates with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, “Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss”. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.’

segments.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti. (4: 61)
segments.en: That is how some assert the extinguishment of an existing being in the present life.

segments.en: But that’s not how *this* self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.

segments.en: Because the bliss and enjoyment there are coarse.

segments.pli: Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti.
segments.en: But giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, this self enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.’

segments.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti. (5: 62)
segments.en: That is how some assert the extinguishment of an existing being in the present life.

segments.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi.
segments.en: These are the five grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert the ultimate extinguishment of an existing being in the present life.

segments.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva pañcahi vatthūhi …
segments.en: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert the ultimate extinguishment of an existing being in the present life do so on one or other of these five grounds. Outside of this there is none.

segments.en: These are the forty-four grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the future assert various hypotheses concerning the future.

segments.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva catucattārīsāya vatthūhi …
segments.en: Any ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the future do so on one or other of these forty-four grounds. Outside of this there is none.
